head.title: POSTINGS: Workshop Wednesday on Historic Sites; Preserving Burial Grounds

hedline.hl1: POSTINGS: Workshop Wednesday on Historic Sites; Preserving Burial Grounds

abstract.p: New York Landmarks Conservancy to sponsor workshop entitled Preserving Historic Burial Grounds; program will cover graveyard architecture, tombstone and memorial restoration, landscaping and fund-raisng (S)

block.p: New York State and the city are dotted with historically significant cemeteries, but, according to the New York Landmarks Conservancy, they lag far behind other communities in protecting their graveyards from the ravages of time.

''The primary problems are overgrown vegetation, vandalism and deterioration of headstones and monuments,'' said Ken Lustbader, director of the conservancy's sacred sites program. ''Many historic headstones are made of marble or brownstone, which in the New York City environment and with acid rain are very vulnerable to damage.''

''The primary problems are overgrown vegetation, vandalism and deterioration of headstones and monuments,'' said Ken Lustbader, director of the conservancy's sacred sites program. ''Many historic headstones are made of marble or brownstone, which in the New York City environment and with acid rain are very vulnerable to damage.''

The organization will sponsor a workshop entitled ''Preserving Historic Burial Grounds'' Wednesday at the German Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Paul at 315 West 22nd Street. The program will cover graveyard architecture, tombstone and memorial restoration, landscaping and fund-raising.

There are at least 100 historic cemeteries in the city, Mr. Lustbader said, dating from the Revolutionary through the Victorian eras. While not banning cemeteries in the city, an 1847 state law encouraged construction in suburban areas. ''They became romantic places to spend an afternoon,'' he said.
Reservations, at (212) 995-5260, are required for the workshop, which costs $35, including a tour of the Shearith Israel cemetery on West 21st Street.
